thread.title: Canadians charged with murders of 2 women in 1988 due in court
thread.title_full: Canadians charged with murders of 2 women in 1988 due in court

author: onlineeditor@nashuatelegraph.com (The Nashua Telegraph)
title: Canadians charged with murders of 2 women in 1988 due in court
text:
Canadians charged with murders of 2 women in 1988 due in court By DEAN SHALHOUPStaff Writer 
NASHUA - David Caplin and Anthony Barnaby, the Canadian men re-arrested in 2011 for mur­der 23 years after they allegedly killed two Nashua women in their Mason Street apartment, are scheduled for separate bail hear­ings later this month, according to documents filed at Hillsborough County Superior Court in Nashua. 
Both are being held without bail at the Valley Street jail in Man­chester as their cases, resurrect­ed when a now-retired Nashua police detective reopened the in­vestigation in 2010, move forward toward their trials, which are tentatively scheduled to start in mid- or late- December, documents in­dicate. ... Digital subscribers receive Unlimited access to all stories from nashuatelegraph.com on your computer, tablet or smart phone. Access nashuatelegraph.com, view our digital edition or use our Full Access apps. Get more information at nashuatelegraph.com/fullaccess Sign up or Login 
NASHUA - David Caplin and Anthony Barnaby, the Canadian men re-arrested in 2011 for mur­der 23 years after they allegedly killed two Nashua women in their Mason Street apartment, are scheduled for separate bail hear­ings later this month, according to documents filed at Hillsborough County Superior Court in Nashua. 
Both are being held without bail at the Valley Street jail in Man­chester as their cases, resurrect­ed when a now-retired Nashua police detective reopened the in­vestigation in 2010, move forward toward their trials, which are tentatively scheduled to start in mid- or late- December, documents in­dicate. 
In a recent development, Cathy J. Green and Ray Rai­mo, the two Manches­ter-based attorneys who ini­tially rep­resented Caplin in the wake of the murders, are back as his defense team, accord­ing to the court file. 
Raimo asked the court to appoint Green as co-coun­cil "because of the serious­ness of the allegations and the complexity of matters" in Caplin's case, according to his motion. 
Prosecutors, documents state, raised no objections to Raimo's motion. 
Caplin's next scheduled appearance in court is a bail hearing set for Friday, Oct. 30. A dispositional con­ference is scheduled for Nov. 9, with trial set to start Dec. 20, documents state. 
Barnaby, meanwhile, is scheduled for a bail hear­ing on Tuesday, Oct. 27, after the court granted prosecutor's motion to re­schedule the hearing from Sept. 15. 
According to his file, Barnaby is scheduled for a dispositional conference on Nov. 18. 
Both men are charged with two first-degree and two second-degree mur­der charges in the deaths of Charlene Ranstrom and Brenda Warner on Oct. 3, 1988. 
Barnaby was tried for the murders three times and each resulted in a hung jury. Caplin was initially arrested in June 1990 and charged in the killings, but never went to trial and had the charges dropped the following month. 
Police say Barnaby re­portedly confessed to beat­ing, tying up and repeat­edly stabbing the women, as well as discussing his hatred of their life­style, but he later re­canted. 
Prosecu­tors initial­ly opted against a fourth trial and Barn­aby returned to Canada, until four years ago when new evidence and addition­al witness accounts led to new warrants in April 2011 for the arrest of Caplin and Barnaby, childhood friends from the Restigouche Indi­an Reservation in Quebec. 
Dean Shalhoup can be reached at 594-6443, dshalhoup@nashua telegraph.com or @Telegraph_ DeanS. Top Jobs
